evidence.text: Person A: Oswald.
Person B: Your friend plays a man with a disfigured face. Name of Edward.

Person B: It’s a sort of beauty and the beast yarn, or am I wrong?
Person A: That’s one way of...
Person B: Just the first stop on the road to glory.
Person B: I’m off then!
Person A: ’ello matey, ow’s the ol’ lady doin’?
Person A: That’s great! ’ow’s tricks, guv?
Person B: ’ow’s tricks, guv?
Person B: I can do German too.
Person B: What are you doing here?

Person A: It might do you some good. They say it’s very relaxing.
Person A: Confidentially, I find it rather a chore, but supposedly it works wonders with our withering bodies. I think I’ve noticed some benefit, but maybe it’s just the placebo effect.
Person B: That’s Guy, he’s a masterful actor.
Person B: I know how it looked, but, don’t get any ideas -
Person B: You are, but only after his transformation.

Person A: And you’re that prince!
Person B: And you’re the beast?
Person A: Not a beast. I’m Edward. This isn’t beauty and the beast.
Person A: She just sees him differently!
Person B: Why can’t it just be him? Why does she have to idealize him so that he’s somebody he isn’t?

Person B: But what a scene! The finale!
Person A: But she loves him for who he is. If he changes, who is he then?

Person B: Edward is not a beast!
Person A: No, of course not, no. But if Beauty and the Beast is our hypothetical point of comparison, well...I mean, let’s be honest with ourselves, old friend.
Person B: Get a good look?

Person A: The mask is mine, I’m keeping it.
Person A: Where’s the blind guy?
Person A: I think you’re kissing my girl.
Person A: Understudy?
Person B: That’s my red door! That’s my couch! These were my lines! Things I said!

Person B: Take yours off! You take yours off! He pulls on Oswald’s face. They wrestle.
Person A: Guy!
Person A: Guy! What have I done? Sometimes I don’t know my own strength!
Person A: Do you remember Fiona? She got ALS. Did you know?

Person B: Eight p.m. sharp.
Person B: You’ll sit with me.
Person A: You’re not in it?
Person B: We’re moving up to Canada. It’s, uh, it’s a place called Shepperton. Do you know of it? It’s - I guess you might call it a nudist colony.
Person B: Well, I don’t know, probably-
Person A: Are your kids going?
Person B: Yes, in broad strokes it does, but it’s really quite leaderless. It’s a radical lifestyle, one that I think will suit us as we get on up there in years.

Person A: Edward, what are you having?
Person A: We’ll need more sake. We’re celebrating. Another bottle of the Dassai Hayata. For the table, wakame, the agedashi tofu, and he needs to try the uni toast. And an order of hamachi kama, why not. And then for my entree, the wagyu flight.
